Um, basically no. 

The atmosphere and ocean equilibrate rapidly. In the large, any added vapour is balanced by suppressing evaporation.

The biggest exception is ‚Äúcorn sweat‚Äù. Large hot irrigated areas  can exacerbate humidity and greenhouse forcing locally. But the global effect is very small.

author: Dr Tom Harris
text: The albedo reduction is partly due to ice loss, but mostly due to a reduction in cloud cover and changes in the make-up of clouds, especially low level clouds in a warming atmosphere. This feedback response amplifies the effect of the greenhouse warming (=138ppm extra CO2).
Nothing absurd about a fact you could look up any time. The first experimental demonstration of the greenhouse effect was in 1859.

The rate of the warming from CO‚ÇÇ Greenhouse Effect is:
-faster in the Winter than the Summer,
-faster on land than the sea, and
-faster in the Northern Hemisphere than the Southern.
These were correctly predicted by Arrhenius in his 1896 climate paper.
The thing that's bad for the earth is becoming a greenhouse. Google greenhouse effect.

author: Robin Wilde
text: Our engagement trip to Glacier National Park was so interesting. Taxi driver complaining that there's not as many glaciers these days, and they're smaller. We said something like "oh climate change is a bit scary isn't it" - immediate U-turn into how it's not that bad, there's plenty left, etc.

Really? Where did it start cooling? When? Does he really think people don't notice the glaciers melting and taking whole towns out? The weeks of temperatures over 100 degrees? The stunning temperature records worldwide? The ice-free Arctic? Really?

author: Cara Giovanetti
text:
Make no mistake, glacial ice is a solid, but it‚Äôs a solid that flows!  Glaciers are so heavy that they deform under their own weight‚Äîon geological timescales, they can even retreat or flow downhill, shaping the landscape in their wakes.

2/6

Yeah, well pump, couple of powerful computers in my house, HVAC, heat pump, air purifiers in multiple rooms. I'm just kind of shocked that the energy consumption is so low compared to an EV which I feel like doesn't even take much energy at all. Certainly cheaper than equivalent gasoline costs.

author: Nafnlaus üáÆüá∏ üá∫üá¶ üá¨üá™
text:
I'll also reiterate that electricity is only a bit over a fifth of global primary energy consumption.

(Be cautious of higher numbers in forecasts for 2030 because they're commonly for "data centres", but remember that most data centre power is actually crypto)

Renewables generated the equivalent of 113% of our electricity consumption, but electricity is only about 20%of our energy consumption. The other 80% is domestic or commercial use of gas, plus domestic oil, and petrol and diesel in vehicles.

author: Nafnlaus üáÆüá∏ üá∫üá¶ üá¨üá™
text: *** - "... responsible for 1,5% of global final energy consumption *growth*."

author: Nafnlaus üáÆüá∏ üá∫üá¶ üá¨üá™
text: Even when represented as share of *growth*, not total energy, it's small.  And furthermore, I see no reason to represent it as a share of growth. It's total energy consumption that matters.  Nothing is static - not datacentre consumption, not *any* consumption.

author: Nafnlaus üáÆüá∏ üá∫üá¶ üá¨üá™
text:
So datacentres - again, which are mostly Bitcoin -  are responsible for ~4% of global electricity growth.

Electricity is about 1/5th of final energy consumption, and global energy grew by 2,2%, so datacentre growth is responsible for 1,5% of global final energy consumption.

author: Nafnlaus üáÆüá∏ üá∫üá¶ üá¨üá™
text: In 2024, datacentres were 1,5% of global electricity (not energy) consumption, with an annual growth rate of ~12% since 2017. Again, by far mostly Bitcoin, not AI, but let's ignore that. That's 0,18% electricity growth per year from datacentres.  Global electricity demand increased by 4,3% in 2024.
